awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Thunderstorm Electrical Energy Structure, Dissipation, and Visualization
awd_abstract_narration:
During this project, a two-year field campaign will measure the turbulent character of thunderstorm flow with two high-resolution weather radars. Comparison of the turbulence data to lightning flash rate and extent will test the hypothesis that turbulent convective motions are the source of electrical energy in storms. The rich textural character of thunderstorm data will be conveyed to the public in an innovative art exhibit. Data and software will be shared openly alongside traditional forms of publication.

Intellectual Merit :
After thunderstorms become electrified, it is of basic interest to understand how often lightning will occur and how extensive those lightning flashes will be. Electrical potential energy stored in a storm's electric field is the result of charge carried on precipitating and non-precipitating hydrometeors which are themselves embedded in the storm's flow. In updraft regions of the storm, where conditions are most favorable for electrification, the storm's flow is highly turbulent, while downstream in anvils or in organized stratiform precipitation regions, flow is smoother. Recent work with a Lightning Mapping Array (LMA) has revealed that a lightning energy spectrum calculated from flash extent and flash rate looks much like the energy spectrum that would be predicted by Kolmogorov's classical turbulence theory for thunderstorm convective plumes. This project will assess turbulent characteristics of thunderstorms using high-resolution radars to quantitatively measure thunderstorm kinematics with weather radars. The combination of radar and LMA data will provide a quantitative test of the hypothesis that turbulence controls the distribution of sizes of charge regions, which in turn controls flash rate and extent. By establishing quantitative links between convective and electrical energy at the range of scales native to both lightning and the convective character of the plume, this project is expected to establish a fundamental new relationship between lightning and deep convection, including a reliable statistical statement about the distribution of flash sizes expected in thunderstorms.

Broader Impacts :
Attending lightning are recreational, commercial and environmental impacts, which makes lightning an area of interest to individuals and formal decision support services provided by and between businesses and government agencies. This project will help clarify the distribution of electrical potential in storms, which controls to a large extent whether a flash strikes ground. The field campaign and its results will be shared at local high schools to stimulate interest in science and mathematics. During the project, artists will produce an immersive gallery exhibit derived from field data. This exhibit will include a survey component to test its effectiveness in presenting lightning data with the rich texture as it actually exists in storms, countering notions of lightning as singleton storm-wide discharges between simple vertically stacked charge layers. Data collection, analysis, and publication of results in a team setting will provide students with scholarly and methodological training through a project that is rich in cross-disciplinary theory and in practical skills tied to observational work. In an era of increasing computational resources and emphasis on data management and digital knowledge dissemination, this project will train students to adopt best practices in reproducible scientific research using open, pan-disciplinary tools enabled by dispersed, diverse internet-based communities.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Challenging and expanding upon previous models of the coupling of lightning formation to meteorological processes in thunderstorms, this project studied the fundamental physical processes constraining where lightning flashes both begin and travel within thunderclouds. We investigated whether eddies in turbulent flow (about 200 m to 2000 m in size, or less than a tenth of the width of the storm) could concentrate electric charge in a way that influences lightning initiation locations and channel paths. Based on earlier work, which lacked turbulence measurements, smaller flashes were expected to be found in regions with more complex, energetic eddy flows. Larger flashes would be expected in smoother flow away from the most vigorous thunderstorm convection.

In 2015 and 2016 we operated mobile Doppler radars and a lightning mapping array during the Kinematic Texture and Lightning Experiment to measure the interior characteristics of thunderstorms near Lubbock, TX. Concurrent balloon launches measured the environment in which those storms developed. Turbulence measurements from the radars showed that lightning did not travel very far from its initiation location in very turbulent regions, especially at high altitudes, while smoother flow was required for the largest flashes, confirming our expectation and adding statistical insights about how flash channels travel within storms.

Using the balloon measurements, we created electrified simulations of thunderstorms with simulated lightning channels in collaboration with NOAA?s National Severe Storm Laboratory. While charge generation and dissipation by lightning tended to be horizontally layered, charge transport by the storm?s flow was highly complex on turbulent eddy scales, and lightning showed some response to this fine scale structure. In contrast with the flow-independent layers that would be expected in textbook models of lightning formation, the average flow near flash initiation locations showed eddy circulations.

The discovery of the characteristic patterns described above makes lightning less random and chaotic than it might otherwise seem. Paradoxically, we identified such patterns by seeking to couple lightning?s behavior to turbulent eddies, another notoriously unpredictable physical system.

Broader Impacts

One doctoral degree and four masters degrees were awarded to students utilizing data collected during this field campaign, leading to several research publications. Four of these five students were from underrepresented groups. Additionally, all students but one (who continued into a current Ph.D. program) have found employment in the field. Over one hundred graduate and undergraduate students participated in annual scientific computing workshops that successfully built capacity for working with state-of-the art tooling as part of a discipline-wide shift toward the Python programming language.

Open-source scientific software developed during this grant was widely used by many other students, faculty, and scientific researchers nationally and internationally. It was also incorporated in projects beyond this grant into methods now used by the U.S. National Weather Service to process and display lightning data from the new Geostationary Lightning Mapper satellite instrument.

The growing understanding that there is an organizing physical logic to the presence of small lightning flashes in thunderstorms? convective towers, and that larger flashes are located in more stratified clouds, has also had downstream impact in the design of products used by in National Weather Service operations. Many of the computational approaches used for processing LMA data were adapted directly to the processing of NOAA's Geostationary Lightning Mapper data concurrently with this project. The basic scientific understanding of the origin of flash size variability pursued under this award was also translated to NOAA/NWS operational training and is now in routine use.

Finally, in collaboration with the artist Tina Fuentes, we staged a museum exhibit, Marcando el Rel?mpago (Marking the Lightning), exploring the complex textures of turbulence and tortuous paths of lightning, both in paintings and large format visualizations of scientific data. Over 30,000 visitors to the museum saw the exhibit during its primary run, and samples and summaries of the exhibit were presented at two other primarily undergraduate institutions in Texas and Indiana.
